statement:
In a ring with a divisor theory, a congruence
$\alpha \equiv \beta \pmod{\mathfrak{a}}$ with respect to a divisor
$\mathfrak{a}$ that $\mathfrak{a} \mid \alpha\!-\!\beta$.\
**Theorem.** Let $\mathcal{O}$ be an integral domain having the divisor
theory $\mathcal{O}^* \to \mathfrak{D}$. For arbitrary pairwise coprime
divisors $\mathfrak{a}_1,\,\ldots,\,\mathfrak{a}_s$ in $\mathfrak{D}$
and for arbitrary elements $\alpha_1,\,\ldots,\,\alpha_s$ of the domain
$\mathcal{O}$ there exists an element $\xi$ in $\mathcal{O}$ such that
$$\begin{aligned}
\begin{cases}
\xi\, \equiv\, \alpha_1 \pmod{\mathfrak{a}_1}\\
\cdots \qquad \cdots \qquad \cdots\\
\xi\, \equiv\, \alpha_s \pmod{\mathfrak{a}_s}
\end{cases}\end{aligned}$$

[*Proof.*]{} Let
$$\mathfrak{b}_i \,:=\, \prod_{j \neq i}\mathfrak{a}_j \quad (i = 1,\,\ldots,\,s).$$
Apparently, the divisors $\mathfrak{b}_1,\,\ldots,\,\mathfrak{b}_s$ are
mutually coprime, whence there are in the ring $\mathcal{O}$ the
elements $\beta_1,\,\ldots,\,\beta_s$ divisible by the divisors
$\mathfrak{b}_1,\,\ldots,\,\mathfrak{b}_s$, respectively, such that
$$\begin{aligned}
\beta_1+\ldots+\beta_s = 1.\end{aligned}$$ For every $i \neq j$, the
divisor $\mathfrak{a}_i$ divides $\mathfrak{b}_j$ and therefore also the
element $\beta_j$. Then the equation (1) implies that
$\beta_i \equiv 1 \pmod{\mathfrak{a}_i}$ and thus the element
$$\xi \,:=\, \alpha_1\beta_1+\ldots+\alpha_s\beta_s$$ satisfies
$$\xi \,\equiv\, \alpha_i\beta_i \,\equiv\, \alpha_i\! \pmod{\mathfrak{a}_i}$$
for each $i = 1,\,\ldots,\,s$. Q.E.D.
